botanical_details.genus: Symphyotrichum includes around 90 species of annuals, biennials and perennials, mostly spread through the Americas, that were formerly included within the genus Aster. Leaves are simple, lance-shaped and entire, but it is their daisy-like flowerheads that they are grown for; central disc florets are typically yellow, surrounded by strap-shaped ray florets in shades of pink, blue, purple or white

how_to_grow.cultivation: Grow in rich, fertile, moisture-retentive soil, in full sun if the soil remains moist throughout the growing season, or in partial shade; mulch every year after cutting down in late autumn. Divide every third year to retain vigour and flower quality. May require support - see staking perennials
how_to_grow.propagation: Propagate by division in spring, replanting only vigorous young shoots
how_to_grow.pruning: Cut back close to the ground in late autumn
how_to_grow.pests: May be affected by eelworm, aphids, slugs and snails
how_to_grow.diseases: May be affected by fusarium foot rot, leaf spot, grey moulds and verticillium wilt. Has some resistance to powdery mildews
